Award.AwardTitle: REU SITE: Undergraduate Research on Complex Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at the University of Vermont offers undergraduates a unique experience working in the emerging area of complex materials, including research related to nanotechnology applications. Over a three year period a total of 27 undergraduates participate in 10-week summer research projects on collective phenomena through studies of self-assembled discotic organic semiconductors, metallic nanopillars and relationships between electronic and magnetic properties of graphene. REU participants also explore how novel deposition methods can drive the self-assembly process towards different ordering with radically different properties, understand the role of short and long range interactions in biological molecules or experiment with new chemistry of polymers, ceramics and nanoporous building blocks for biomedical applications.

A diverse group of students is recruited from across the nation. REU participants gain experience identifying research problems, searching the literature, conducting research, and communicating their findings. Research on complex materials, in addition to contributing fundamental knowledge, has applications in the important areas of nanotechnology and biotechnology, where many of most challenging current problems and issues are found. The research impacts potential solutions in areas such as emerging mass-production organic technologies, air pollution monitoring and mitigation, new energy-efficient consumer products, and technology for medical treatment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Vermont summer REU program on complex materials focuses on engaging undergraduate students across the US in experimental and theoretical research on frontier issues concerning materials science and related fields.  We provide the student cohort with instruction on topics and techniques intrinsic to the research process, including oral and written presentation of scientific results and ethical issues related to conducting research.

Our goals are (1) to provide a high quality research experience to a diverse and talented group of undergraduates, and (2) to encourage and stimulate the student cohort to pursue careers in STEM-related fields.  

Over the period of the award, we selected 27 student participants from over 300 applications.  Results of research projects were presented by the participating students in 4 symposia open to the public at the University of Vermont.  Several major publications and a number of conference papers resulted directly from the research.  Some representative examples of research projects include:

1) van der Waals forces and electron interactions in strained graphene

2) experimental studies of pressure and atmosphere of the formation of WSi2 and Si nanoclusters

3) simulation studies of the mechanical properties of nanowires

4) excitonic properties of TPP thin films

5) superfluid properties of liquid Helium

6) circular dichroism studies of the axial ligand effects on IsdG secondary structure

7) synthesis of the first As-C polymer

8) quantum sticking of atomic hydrogen to graphene

9) organic photovoltaics and TCOs

10) studies of polyvinyl alcohol scaffolds

11) optical studies of the properties of organic semiconductors
